docs.lead_paragraph: Policy experts and others are weighing the repercussions of a possible decision by the Supreme Court to strike down the federal health care law.

headline.main: Sense of Peril for Health Law Gives Insurers Pause
headline.print_headline: A Health Law At Risk Gives Insurers Pause

docs.abstract: Insurers, hospitals and policy experts are weighing the widespread repercussions that would result should the Supreme Court strike down the health care law, forcing them to abandon major changes and billions of dollars spent since the law was passed in 2010; reversal would be particularly difficult for insurance companies, which have adapted to numerous provisions of the law that have already been implemented.
docs.snippet: Policy experts and others are weighing the repercussions of a possible decision by the Supreme Court to strike down the federal health care law.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and KATIE THOMAS

docs.lead_paragraph: More Americans should take the initiative to spell out what treatments they do — and do not — want by writing living wills and appointing health care proxies.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by writer Susan Jacoby argues that more Americans should take the initiative to spell out what end-of-life medical treatments they do--and do not--want by writing living wills and appointing health care proxies.
docs.snippet: More Americans should take the initiative to spell out what treatments they do — and do not — want by writing living wills and appointing health care proxies.

keywords.value: Living Wills and Health Care Proxies
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: If the Supreme Court limits the commerce clause in striking down the health care law, it could have unintended consequences on Congress’s ability to legislate.

headline.seo: If the Health Care Mandate Goes, the Commerce Clause Might Follow
headline.main: Broccoli Mandates and the Commerce Clause

docs.abstract: James B Stewart Common Sense column contends that the increasing likelihood that the Supreme Court will strike down the Affordable Care Act is a tribute to the persuasive power of conservative media and what seems a breathtaking departure from decades of Supreme Court jurisprudence; argues that the increasingly nationalized insurance market clearly falls within Congressional jurisdiction, and that conservatives should be wary of undoing decades of judicial deference to the Commerce Clause of the Constitution.
docs.snippet: If the Supreme Court limits the commerce clause in striking down the health care law, it could have unintended consequences on Congress’s ability to legislate.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal court ruled last week that the F.D.A. must finally decide whether the routine practice of feeding antibiotics to healthy farm animals poses a serious danger to human health. If the F.D.A. concludes that it does, they must ban the practice. (My best guess is that the F.D.A. will hold true to form and wind up caving to the meat industry, but if I'm wrong I'll apologize and join the celebration.)

headline.main: The Supreme Court and the National Conversation on Health Care Reform

docs.abstract: Many Americans seem to feel they have a right to all the health care they need but should not be required to make provisions beforehand to pay for it, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Many Americans seem to feel they have a right to all the health care they need but should not be required to make provisions beforehand to pay for it, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: In making their arguments to the Supreme Court about the health law, advocates tried to win over Justice Anthony M. Kennedy by invoking one of his most valued principles: liberty.

headline.seo: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy May Be Key to Health Law Ruling
headline.main: In Health Case, Appeals to a Justice’s Idea of Liberty
headline.print_headline: Appealing to a Justice’s Notion of Liberty

docs.abstract: News analysis; in making their arguments to the Supreme Court about Pres Obama's health care law, advocates are hoping to win over Justice Anthony M Kennedy by invoking one of his most valued principles: liberty; if the administration is to prevail in the case and see the law upheld, it must capture at least one vote beyond those of the court's four more liberal justices, and Justice Kennedy is its best hope.
docs.snippet: In making their arguments to the Supreme Court about the health law, advocates tried to win over Justice Anthony M. Kennedy by invoking one of his most valued principles: liberty.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Studies have found that justices tend to ask more questions of the lawyers whose positions they oppose. During arguments this week over three questions on the health care law, like-minded justices tended to focus their questions on the same lawyers.

headline.seo: In Questions Asked, Hints on the Court’s Views
headline.main: In Number of Questions Asked, Hints on the Court’s Views

docs.snippet: Studies have found that justices tend to ask more questions of the lawyers whose positions they oppose. During arguments this week over three questions on the health care law, like-minded justices tended to focus their questions on the same lawyers.

docs.lead_paragraph: From Pedro Espada Jr., who is accused of embezzling from his Bronx clinics, to the Supreme Court justice who casts the deciding vote on the individual mandate, so much in health care depends on one person.

headline.seo: From Espada to the Supreme Court, Health Care Hinges on One Person
headline.main: Here to There, It All Hinges on One Person
headline.print_headline: Here to There, It All Hinges On One Man

docs.abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column asserts that trial of Pedro G Espada and Pedro Espada Jr, who are charged with stealing $500,000 from Soundview Health Care clinics in the Bronx, bears similarity to fact that national health care may come down to one deciding vote in the Supreme Court; says that both situations highlight the perils of entrusting a great deal of power to a single person.
docs.snippet: From Pedro Espada Jr., who is accused of embezzling from his Bronx clinics, to the Supreme Court justice who casts the deciding vote on the individual mandate, so much in health care depends on one person.

docs.lead_paragraph: A fierce two-day debate over a Republican budget plan portrayed as either a path to prosperity or a road to ruin ended on Thursday.

headline.main: House Passes G.O.P. Budget Plan, Mostly Along Party Lines
headline.print_headline: House Passes Its Budget Blueprint, Mostly Along Party Lines

docs.abstract: House votes 228 to 191 to pass a budget blueprint that would transform Medicare, cut domestic spending to levels not seen since World War II and order up a drastic overhaul of the tax code; passage follows two days of fierce debate in which bill was alternately portrayed as a path to prosperity or a road to financial ruin; budget is likely to form the framework for much of the debate in the 2012 election.
docs.snippet: A fierce two-day debate over a Republican budget plan portrayed as either a path to prosperity or a road to ruin ended on Thursday.
